content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. Within these fragments, there are at least three structures consistent with lymph nodes. These nodes are largely replaced by dense, dark purple (basophilic) cellular infiltrates, which is highly suspicious for extensive metastatic carcinoma. The normal architecture of the lymph nodes appears to be effaced by these deposits.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed at the interface between the large, suspicious lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. This is a critical area to examine. The primary reason to zoom in here is to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is defined as tumor cells breaching the lymph node capsule and invading the adjacent fat. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor, and this interface is the specific location where it must be evaluated. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area on the large lymph node to the left to examine the interface between the dense tumor infiltrate and the surrounding perinodal fat. This specific location is crucial for assessing extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the adjacent soft tissue. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor and needs to be carefully evaluated and reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the large metastatic deposit in the lower-left tissue fragment. This specific area is at the interface between the main tumor mass and the surrounding adipose tissue. The purpose of examining this junction is to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the perinodal fat. ENE is a critical prognostic factor, and this is the precise location to identify it. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to systematically examine every potential lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is a well-defined, densely cellular nodule within the upper-right tissue fragment, which is morphologically consistent with a lymph node. I am zooming into this specific area to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification to determine if it is a benign/reactive node or if it contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is one of the lymph nodes that appears to be involved by tumor. The zoomed-in area is located at the interface between the solid tumor deposit and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. I am zooming into this specific location to assess for extranodal extension (ENE). ENE is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat, which is a significant adverse prognostic factor and is critical for accurate staging. I need to examine this border at high power to see if the tumor has a smooth, pushing border or an irregular, infiltrative border. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify any lymph nodes containing metastatic tumor. I would systematically examine every potential lymph node on the slide. The green box is placed over one of the distinct, darkly stained nodules on the right-hand piece of tissue. Zooming into this area is essential to examine the cellular morphology and architecture to confirm if this is a lymph node and, if so, to determine whether the high cellularity is due to a benign reactive process or malignant infiltration. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the interface between a dense, monotonous sheet of malignant-appearing cells (on the right) and mature adipose tissue (on the left). The cellular infiltrate has replaced the normal lymph node tissue. The border between the tumor and the fat is not smooth or encapsulated; instead, it is irregular and infiltrative. There are nests and clusters of tumor cells extending directly into the surrounding adipose tissue. This finding is diagnostic of extranodal extension (ENE), confirming that the metastasis has spread beyond the confines of the lymph node capsule.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see sheets and nests of malignant cells infiltrating the adipose tissue. The tumor cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. They are seen dissecting between individual adipocytes, both in clusters and as single cells. This finding unequivocally confirms the presence of extranodal extension. The lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows adipose tissue (large white circles) being infiltrated by nests and cords of malignant cells. These cells are dark, crowded, and have atypical nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The presence of these tumor cells clearly within the perinodal fat, separate from the main tumor mass, confirms extranodal extension (ENE). This is a positive lymph node with ENE.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The normal lymph node architecture appears somewhat effaced by this dense lymphoid infiltrate. On the lower-left, there is infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue. Critically, I do not see any definitive nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular formation, or cells with large, irregular nuclei and prominent nucleoli that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node that is negative for malignancy. The dense cellularity is most likely due to a reactive process (e.g., follicular hyperplasia).
This is ROI 5. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells on the right, characterized by high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios, hyperchromatic nuclei, and cellular crowding. These features are consistent with metastatic carcinoma. On the left is mature adipose tissue. The crucial finding is that the tumor cells are directly and irregularly infiltrating into the adipose tissue, with small nests and individual cells intermingling with the fat cells. There is no intervening fibrous capsule. My impression is metastatic carcinoma in a lymph node with definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells that has largely replaced the normal lymph node parenchyma. The malignant cells are characterized by pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. They are arranged in poorly formed glands and nests, infiltrating the residual lymphoid tissue and the adjacent perinodal adipose tissue on the left. My impression is unequivocal: this is a lymph node extensively involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma. The presence of tumor in the fat outside the node's capsule would also be assessed for extranodal extension.
